awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Prediction of coronavirus infections and complications at the individual and the population levels from genomic, proteomic, clinical and behavioral data sources
awd_abstract_narration:
As of mid-April 2020, two million people are infected worldwide with the novel coronavirus that first appeared in Wuhan, China in December of 2019.  Now, the USA is at the epicenter of this pandemic, where it has already killed 20,000 people. Approaches to slow the progression are urgently needed. This requires a better fundamental understanding of the factors affecting not only virus spread, but also who develops complications and ultimately dies from the infection. It is becoming clear that many factors are at play, including molecular, physiological, lifestyle, behavioral, demographic and socio-economic ones. In particular, co-morbidities such as diabetes and high blood pressure are known risk factors for COVID-19 complications and death but are likely only the tip of the iceberg. Molecular data indicates that as many as 100 co-morbidities exist. Given this complexity, statistical approaches are needed to integrate and account for all of these factors when predicting and assessing the health risks arising from coronavirus spread and infection. This project will create computational tools that will help individuals and healthcare professionals make decisions related to coronavirus, helping target human and material resources where they are most needed. To decrease the numbers of people suffering from this pandemic, these tools are needed urgently.

Integrating large numbers of risk factors through machine-learning approaches allows the building of statistical models that take all evidence into account. COVID-19 infections will be predicted at the individual and population levels. At the individual level, two binary (yes/no) classifiers will be built, (1) if an individual is likely infected with coronavirus, and if yes, (2) will the patient develop complications. As with all predictions, they cannot replace real data, but they can help prioritize who gets tested, who gets quarantined, who gets more closely monitored for signs of complications, and who gets personalized recommendations. Existing approaches include symptom-tracker apps, such as the coronavirus self-checker apps offered by the CDC, many healthcare providers and local government authorities and the National Early Warning Score (NEWS) and Modified Early Warning Score (MEWS), which determine the degree of illness of a patient. None of these approaches account for co-morbidities, and they lack the use of machine learning for data integration needed to predict individual outcomes. At the population level, possible routes of infection will be analyzed using graph analysis, through analysis of proximity, social interactions, and materials transport, taking the individual-level information into account where available. The project will be highly interdisciplinary, integrating biochemistry and computer science with ongoing input and feedback from healthcare professionals. This will ensure that the work will be relevant to the current crisis and easier to adopt by healthcare providers. Students and postdocs who participate in this research will be trained in interdisciplinary research and will be exposed directly to frontline workers in the pandemic. A publicly available, free app and a web interface will disseminate the predictions made in this project broadly in the hope it will find many users.

In summary, the goal of this research is to understand how SARS-CoV-2 virus and host genomes interact to determine the full spectrum of disease outcomes, with the goals of identifying the cellular basis for host range and pathology, predicting morbidit,; and developing effective medical interventions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TRUSTEES OF THE COLORADO SCHOOL OF MINES

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Scientific merit

This proposal was funded in response to the infection of the world with the novel coronavirus (COVID-19). At the time the grant was funded, a fundamental understanding of the factors affecting who develops complications and ultimately dies from the infection was not known, except that many factors are involved. The purpose of this grant was to integrate these factors through statistical approaches to predict and assess the health risks arising from coronavirus spread and infection. We created computational tools to assist individuals and healthcare professionals in coronavirus-related decision-making in order alleviate exhaustion of human and material resources. COVID-19 infections were predicted at the individual and at the population levels. At the individual level, two binary (yes/no) classifiers were built, (1) if an individual is likely infected with the virus, and if yes, (2) will the patient develop complications. At the population levels, forecasting models were built aimed to predict the spread of the virus. We presented novel approaches to handle temporal and missing data problems simultaneously. Thus, the COVID-19 prediction task required the development of general computational methodological advances that may also prove important in other domains.

In addition to infection prediction, we also studied disease mechanisms and avenues for drug discovery. Results on molecular COVID data included predictions of protein protein interaction, and repurposing of existing drugs for treatment of COVID infections and structure-function studies of human proteins targeted by the virus that may be responsible for co-morbidies such as insulin receptor (COVID co-morbidity diabetes) and alpha-synuclein (COVID co-morbidity dementia). We also studied antibiotics since it was reported that antibiotics can lower COVID symptoms.

We have produced 17 outcomes, including one website, one app, one unpublished technology and 15 published papers. Our work has also been publicized in multiple news media.

 

Broader Impacts

In addition to the scientific contributions and publications, we have furthered cross-disciplinary collaboration on molecular COVID data. To this end, we have participated in an effort to combat the COVID-19 crisis through transparent, wide-ranging, cross-disciplinary collaboration in the "cure COVid for Ever and for All" (RxCOVEA) consortium.

The project was highly interdisciplinary, integrating biochemistry and computer science with continuous input and feedback from healthcare professionals. This ensured that the work had relevance for the current crisis and will find adoption by healthcare providers. Students and postdocs who participated in this research were not only trained in interdisciplinary research but were exposed directly to frontline workers in the pandemic.

The impact that COVID-19 had on our daily lives served as a major motivator for undergraduate and graduate student to conduct research on COVID-19 in this project. A hallmark of this project was the integration of research with education, as a large number of graduate and undergraduate students have been involved in the project through courses taught be the PI and projects offered in several computer science field sessions. 16 undergraduate students (unpaid, through course credit) and 5 undergraduate students (paid) were involved in the project. 33 graduate students (unpaid, through course credit) and 2 graduate students (paid) were involved in the project. They all experienced interdisciplinary education and interaction with health and IT professionals. 

We have also engaged in outreach to general public and stakeholders. As the PI of Mines@Catalyst, I was the driver of engagement with the Denver Catalyst, a building housing more than 50 companies and community stakeholder organizations. Through networking events and collaborations with Mines, we have been able to directly engage these companies in our work. Using the Mines@Catalyst venture has also allowed us to communicate our projects through our project website: https://catalyst.mines.edu/call-for-action-covid-19/

 


Last Modified: 10/18/2022
Modified by: Judith Klein

Image
  • In this proposal, machine learning methods were developed to integrate diverse data to predict COVID infection and complications risks.
    Judith Klein-Seetharaman
    Copyrighted
    Judith Klein
    The future iCOVID risk prediction interface.
